Sentences_to: He rushed into his room in his dressing-gown and was back again in a few seconds in a frock-coat.
Translated_sentences: He ran out of the room in his dressing-gown; a minute later he appeared in his frock-coat.

Sentences_from: Kamienne siedziby naszych przodków zasiewają gęsto oparzelisko, i dziwić się należy, dlaczego oni osiedlali się w tych bagnach?
Sentences_to: As you look at their gray stone huts against the scarred hill-sides you leave your own age behind you, and if you were to see a skin-clad, hairy man crawl out from the low door fitting a flint-tipped arrow on to the string of his bow, you would feel that his presence there was more natural than your own.
Translated_sentences: The stone dwellings of our ancestors sow densely in the burn, and one wonders why they settled in these swamps?

Sentences_from: Wiedział, gdzie mieszkam, w jakim interesie sir Henryk przybył do mnie; poznał mnie na Regent-Street; domyślił się, że spostrzegłem numer dorożkarza, że go sprowadzę, i dlatego wymienił moje nazwisko. Powiadam ci, Watson, mamy przeciwnika nielada.
Sentences_to: "The cunning rascal! He knew our number, knew that Sir Henry Baskerville had consulted me, spotted who I was in Regent Street, conjectured that I had got the number of the cab and would lay my hands on the driver, and so sent back this audacious message.
Translated_sentences: He knew where I lived, on what business Sir Henry had come to see me; he met me in Regent-Street; he guessed that I had noticed the cabman's number, that I would bring him in, and so he mentioned my name. I tell you, Watson, we have a formidable opponent.

Sentences_from: W chwili, gdyś mnie odnalazł na moczarach, miałem już w ręku wszystkie nici spisku, lecz nie posiadałem materyału dowodowego, z którym mógłbym stanąć przed sądem.
Sentences_to: This also you cleared up in a very effective way, though I had already come to the same conclusions from my own observations.
Translated_sentences: At the moment when you found me in the marshes, I already had all the threads of the conspiracy in my hand, but I had no evidence with which I could stand trial.

Sentences_from: -- Przepraszam cię -- rzekłem. -- Czy mógłbyś mi wyjaśnić, kto żywił psa podczas pobytu Stapletona w Londynie?
Sentences_to: "One moment!" said I. "You have, no doubt, described the sequence of events correctly, but there is one point which you have left unexplained. What became of the hound when its master was in London?"
Translated_sentences: -- Excuse me -- I said. -- could you explain to me who fed the dog while Stapleton was in London?

Sentences_from: Powiedz mi otwarcie: co ci się nie podoba?
Sentences_to: I have come here with no object except to help him. Tell me, frankly, what it is that you don't like."
Translated_sentences: Tell me openly: what don't you like?

Sentences_from: Wreszcie Stapleton skinął na siostrę, która po chwili wahania poszła za nim, rzuciwszy spojrzenie baronetowi.
Sentences_to: "Halloa, Watson! Where have you dropped from?" said he. "You don't mean to say that you came after me in spite of all?"
Translated_sentences: At last Stapleton nodded to his sister, who, after a moment's hesitation, followed him, casting a glance at the baronet.

Sentences_from: -- Więc chcecie mnie opuścić? -- powtórzył sir Henryk. -- Wszak twoja rodzina służyła mojej przez kilka pokoleń. Przykroby mi było rozpoczynać nowe życie od zrywania tak dawnego stosunku.
Sentences_to: "Only when it is quite convenient to you, sir."
Translated_sentences: -- So you wish to leave me? -- repeated Sir Henry. -- after all, your family has served mine for several generations. I was sorry to start a new life by breaking such an old relationship.

Sentences_from: Rumieniec znikł z jej twarzy, w jednej chwili zbladła śmiertelnie.
Sentences_to: The flush had faded in an instant, and a deathly face was before me.
Translated_sentences: The blush disappeared from her face, she turned deathly pale in an instant.

Sentences_from: On ma w oczach groźne błyski, a zacięte usta zdradzają naturę twardą i nieubłaganą.
Sentences_to: There is a dry glitter in his eyes, and a firm set of his thin lips, which goes with a positive and possibly a harsh nature.
Translated_sentences: He has menacing flashes in his eyes, and his fierce mouth betrays a nature that is hard and unrelenting.

Sentences_from: Wśród zielska i trawy wyzierał jakiś czarny przedmiot.
Sentences_to: Once only we saw a trace that someone had passed that perilous way before us.
Translated_sentences: A black object was peeking out from among the weeds and grass.

Sentences_from: Treść drugiej depeszy była następująca: „Zwiedziłem dwadzieścia trzy hotele wskazane, ale nie mogłem znaleźć owego _Timesa_.
Sentences_to: "Visited twenty-three hotels as directed, but sorry, to report unable to trace cut sheet of Times.--CARTWRIGHT."
Translated_sentences: The contents of the second dispatch were as follows: "I visited the twenty-three hotels indicated, but could not find this _Times_.

Sentences_from: -- Nie. Przyszliśmy tutaj, aby schwytać mordercę i nie cofniemy się w pół drogi.
Sentences_to: "No, by thunder; we have come out to get our man, and we will do it. We after the convict, and a hell-hound, as likely as not, after us.
Translated_sentences: -- No. We came here to catch a murderer, and we're not going back halfway.

Sentences_from: Serdeczne słowa Holmesa rozproszyły mój żal do niego, tembardziej, iż czułem, że lepiej się stało, żem nie wiedział o jego przebywaniu na bagnie.
Sentences_to: I was still rather raw over the deception which had been practised upon me, but the warmth of Holmes's praise drove my anger from my mind. I felt also in my heart that he was right in what he said and that it was really best for our purpose that I should not have known that he was upon the moor.
Translated_sentences: Holmes' cordial words dissipated my grief for him, especially as I felt it was better that I did not know of his being in the swamp.

Sentences_from: Nie namyślając się, wszedł do pokoju.
Sentences_to: He walked into the room, and as he did so Barrymore sprang up from the window with a sharp hiss of his breath and stood, livid and trembling, before us.
Translated_sentences: Without thinking, he entered the room.

Sentences_from: Pochlebiam sobie, że każda piędź ziemi jest mi teraz dobrze znana.
Sentences_to: He is not a man with intimate friends. Where, then, could he have been?
Translated_sentences: I flatter myself that every heel of the earth is now well known to me.

Sentences_from: Należy przedewszystkiem rozstrzygnąć dwa zagadnienia: popierwsze, czy zaszła zbrodnia? Powtóre: w jaki sposób ją spełniono?
Sentences_to: There are two questions waiting for us at the outset. The one is whether any crime has been committed at all; the second is, what is the crime and how was it committed?
Translated_sentences: There are two questions that need to be answered first of all: Firstly, was there a crime? Second..: in what way was it fulfilled?

Sentences_from: Do tego słupa uwiązana była postać ludzka; w pierwszej chwili nie mogliśmy poznać: czy to mężczyzna, czy kobieta.
Sentences_to: To this post a figure was tied, so swathed and muffled in the sheets which had been used to secure it that one could not for the moment tell whether it was that of a man or a woman.
Translated_sentences: A human figure was tethered to this pole; at first we could not tell if it was a man or a woman.

Sentences_from: -- Wiem, dlaczego był przy furtce o tej godzinie.
Sentences_to: "I know why he was at the gate at that hour.
Translated_sentences: -- I know why he was at the gate at that hour.

Sentences_from: Płonęło ono niewątpliwie w domu Stapletona.
Sentences_to: It could only come from the lonely abode of the Stapletons.
Translated_sentences: It was undoubtedly burning in Stapleton's house.

Sentences_from: Nie ułożyliśmy planu kampanii, ale baronet uważa prostą drogę za najkrótszą i najwłaściwszą.
Sentences_to: We had arranged no plan of campaign, but the baronet is a man to whom the most direct way is always the most natural.
Translated_sentences: We have not laid out a plan of campaign, but the Baronet considers the straight path to be the shortest and most appropriate.

Sentences_from: -- Musisz się wymówić. On pójdzie sam.
Sentences_to: "Then you must excuse yourself and he must go alone.
Translated_sentences: -- you must excuse yourself. He'll go alone.

Sentences_from: Ten człowiek chłodny, nieprzenikniony, do którego od pierwszej chwili wstręt uczułem, wydawał mi się teraz potworem o słodkim uśmiechu.
Sentences_to: In that impassive, colourless man, with his straw hat and his butterfly-net, I seemed to see something terrible--a creature of infinite patience and craft, with a smiling face and a murderous heart.
Translated_sentences: This cold, impenetrable man, for whom I had felt repulsion from the first moment, now seemed to me a monster with a sweet smile.

Sentences_from: Wiatr niósł go wśród nocnej ciszy; z początku było to ciche warczenie, niebawem przeszło w straszne wycie.
Sentences_to: It came with the wind through the silence of the night, a long, deep mutter, then a rising howl, and then the sad moan in which it died away. Again and again it sounded, the whole air throbbing with it, strident, wild, and menacing.
Translated_sentences: The wind carried him amidst the night silence; at first it was a quiet growl, soon it passed into a terrible howl.

Sentences_from: Dokoła nie było widać żadnego żywego stworzenia.
Sentences_to: I looked round, with a chill of fear in my heart, at the huge swelling plain, mottled with the green patches of rushes. Nothing stirred over the vast expanse save a pair of ravens, which croaked loudly from a tor behind us.
Translated_sentences: No living creature was visible around.

Sentences_from: -- Nie potrafię pana objaśnić w tym względzie.
Sentences_to: "I am afraid that I cannot answer that question."
Translated_sentences: -- I can't explain you on that.

Sentences_from: -- To bardzo ważny szczegół -- poświadczył. -- Wypełnia lukę, której nie zdołałem pokryć.
Sentences_to: "This is most important," said he when I had concluded. "It fills up a gap which I had been unable to bridge, in this most complex affair.
Translated_sentences: -- It's a very important detail -- he testified. -- fills in a gap that I haven't been able to cover.

Sentences_from: -- Nędznik!... -- zawołał Holmes z oburzeniem. -- Dawaj no tu flaszkę z wódką -- rzekł do Lestrada. -- Trzeba ją posadzić na krześle i rozcierać.
Sentences_to: "The brute!" cried Holmes. "Here, Lestrade, your brandy-bottle! Put her in the chair! She has fainted from ill-usage and exhaustion."
Translated_sentences: -- Wretched man! -- cried Holmes with indignation. -- Give me that bottle of vodka -- he said to Lestrad. -- He had to put her in a chair and rub her down.

Sentences_from: -- Oto twoje sprawozdania -- rzekł. -- Dostawałem je z 24 godzinnem opóźnieniem i oddały mi znaczne usługi.
Sentences_to: "Here are your reports, my dear fellow, and very well thumbed, I assure you. I made excellent arrangements, and they are only delayed one day upon their way.
Translated_sentences: -- Here are your reports -- he said. -- I received them 24 hours late and they did me considerable service.

Sentences_from: Przysięgam panu, iż pisząc ten list, nie wiedziałam, że narażam na niebezpieczeństwo sir Karola, który był dla mnie lepszym od rodzonego ojca.
Sentences_to: One thing I swear to you, and that is that when I wrote the letter I never dreamed of any harm to the old gentleman, who had been my kindest friend."
Translated_sentences: I swear to you that in writing this letter I did not know that I was endangering Sir Charles, who was better to me than my birth father.

Sentences_from: -- Mam nadzieję, że wyjaśnienie mojego przyjaciela zostanie uznane jako jedynie możliwe.
Sentences_to: "Yes, indeed. I have no doubt that my friend's explanation will cover the facts.
Translated_sentences: -- I hope my friend's explanation will be recognized as only possible.

Sentences_from: Rzucił się naprzód, ja za nim.
Sentences_to: He had started running swiftly over the moor, and I had followed at his heels.
Translated_sentences: He dashed forward, I followed.

Sentences_from: -- Powiem panu szczerze: przewiduję nowe nieszczęście...
Sentences_to: "Look at Sir Charles's death! That was bad enough, for all that the coroner said.
Translated_sentences: -- I'll tell you frankly, I foresee a new calamity...

Sentences_from: -- Skręcił kark, spadając z tej skały.
Sentences_to: "He appears to have broken his neck by falling over these rocks.
Translated_sentences: -- he broke his neck falling off that rock.

Sentences_from: Chwilami zdawało nam się, że jest blizkiem, to znów że bardzo odległem.
Sentences_to: There is nothing so deceptive as the distance of a light upon a pitch-dark night, and sometimes the glimmer seemed to be far away upon the horizon and sometimes it might have been within a few yards of us.
Translated_sentences: At times it seemed to us that he was near, then again that he was very distant.

Sentences_from: Żyzna okolica pozostała za nami; mieliśmy przed sobą ziemię szarą, jałową, zrzadka ukazywała się ludzka siedziba, opasana murem z kamieni. Wreszcie wjechaliśmy w jar głęboki; roztoczyła się znowu zieleń drzew, a w oddali ukazały się dwie strzeliste wieże. Stangret wskazał biczem.
Sentences_to: We had left the fertile country behind and beneath us. We looked back on it now, the slanting rays of a low sun turning the streams to threads of gold and glowing on the red earth new turned by the plough and the broad tangle of the woodlands. The road in front of us grew bleaker and wilder over huge russet and olive slopes, sprinkled with giant boulders. Now and then we passed a moorland cottage, walled and roofed with stone, with no creeper to break its harsh outline. Suddenly we looked down into a cup-like depression, patched with stunted oaks and firs which had been twisted and bent by the fury of years of storm. Two high, narrow towers rose over the trees. The driver pointed with his whip.
Translated_sentences: The fertile countryside remained behind us; the land before us was grey and barren, and seldom did a human dwelling appear, girt by a wall of stones. At last we entered a deep ravine; the green of the trees spread out again, and in the distance two soaring towers appeared. The steward pointed with his whip.

Sentences_from: Więc znowu jedna zagadka powiększyła szereg drobnych tajemnic, następujących tak szybko po sobie.
Sentences_to: The German was sent for but professed to know nothing of the matter, nor could any inquiry clear it up.
Translated_sentences: So again, one mystery has magnified a series of minor mysteries, following so quickly after each other.

Sentences_from: Zwiodłem wszystkich, nie wyłączając ciebie, i zjawiłem się potajemnie, wówczas, gdy sądziliście wszyscy, że bawię w Londynie.
Sentences_to: I deceived everybody, therefore, yourself included, and I came down secretly when I was supposed to be in London.
Translated_sentences: I deceived everyone, including you, and came secretly when you all thought I was in London.

Sentences_from: -- Wszelkie wątpliwości rozprasza fakt, że słowa zostały wycięte w całości, nie zaś pojedynczemi literami, a nawet widzimy dwa słowa wycięte razem: _dbasz o_...
Sentences_to: "If any possible doubt remained it is settled by the fact that 'keep away' and 'from the' are cut out in one piece."
Translated_sentences: -- Any doubt is dispelled by the fact that the words are cut out in full, not in single letters, and we even see two words cut out together: _you care_....

Sentences_from: -- To zapewne potwierdzenie jakiejś legendy -- wtrącił Holmes.
Sentences_to: "It appears to be a statement of some sort."
Translated_sentences: -- This is probably a confirmation of some legend -- Holmes interjected.

Sentences_from: Jest to jedna ze wskazówek, która mi pomogła do określenia daty.
Sentences_to: It is one of several indications which enabled me to fix the date."
Translated_sentences: This is one of the tips that helped me to determine the date.

Sentences_from: Najlepiej Seldonowi twarz zakryć, a zwłoki będą bezpieczne do jutra rana.
Sentences_to: I think that if we put something over his face he will be safe until morning."
Translated_sentences: Best to cover Seldon's face and the corpse will be safe until tomorrow morning.

Sentences_from: „Wkrótce potem, Hugon, zostawiwszy swoich kompanów przy butelkach i kartach, podążył do swojej ofiary, a widząc, że ptaszek opuścił klatkę, jak szalony powrócił do komnaty biesiadnej, wytłukł szkło i wśród okropnych przekleństw i złorzeczeń zaprzysiągł, że odda ciało i duszę dyabłu, jeśli ten dopomoże mu odzyskać dziewczynę.
Sentences_to: "It chanced that some little time later Hugo left his guests to carry food and drink--with other worse things, perchance--to his captive, and so found the cage empty and the bird escaped. Then, as it would seem, he became as one that hath a devil, for, rushing down the stairs into the dining-hall, he sprang upon the great table, flagons and trenchers flying before him, and he cried aloud before all the company that he would that very night render his body and soul to the Powers of Evil if he might but overtake the wench.
Translated_sentences: "Soon after, Hugon, leaving his companions to their bottles and cards, went to his victim, and seeing that the bird had left the cage, like a madman he returned to the feasting-chamber, broke the glass, and amidst terrible curses and maledictions swore that he would give body and soul to the dyabe if he would help him to recover the girl.

Sentences_from: Staliśmy, nasłuchując, ale żaden dźwięk nie wpadł nam w ucho.
Sentences_to: We stood straining our ears, but nothing came.
Translated_sentences: We stood, listening, but no sound came into our ears.

Sentences_from: Dalej: na kogo czekał owej nocy i dlaczego czekał w Alei Wiązów, zamiast w domu?
Sentences_to: Then, again, whom was he waiting for that night, and why was he waiting for him in the Yew Alley rather than in his own house?"
Translated_sentences: Further: who was he waiting for that night, and why was he waiting in Elm Avenue instead of at home?

Sentences_from: -- Niewątpliwie -- potwierdził mój przyjaciel.
Sentences_to: "And the warning--it must have come from her!"
Translated_sentences: -- Undoubtedly -- confirmed my friend.

Sentences_from: Donosiliśmy często na tych szpaltach o jego hojnych ofiarach na instytucye publiczne. „Śledztwo nie wyjaśniło dotychczas okoliczności, towarzyszących śmierci sir Karola.
Sentences_to: Their evidence, corroborated by that of several friends, tends to show that Sir Charles's health has for some time been impaired, and points especially to some affection of the heart, manifesting itself in changes of colour, breathlessness, and acute attacks of nervous depression.
Translated_sentences: We have often reported in these columns on his generous donations to public institutions. "The inquest has not yet clarified the circumstances surrounding Sir Charles' death.

Sentences_from: -- Widzisz pan, że miałem słuszność -- rzekł Holmes. -- Obstaję dalej przy moich hypotezach, że doktor Mortimer musi być uprzejmy, bo tylko człowiek uprzejmy dostaje takie upominki od swoich pacyentów; że nie jest ambitny, bo inaczej nie opuszczałby Londynu dla prowincyi, i że jest roztargniony, bo w razie przeciwnym, zamiast laski, zostawiłby swój bilet wizytowy.
Sentences_to: "No mention of that local hunt, Watson," said Holmes with a mischievous smile, "but a country doctor, as you very astutely observed. I think that I am fairly justified in my inferences. As to the adjectives, I said, if I remember right, amiable, unambitious, and absent-minded. It is my experience that it is only an amiable man in this world who receives testimonials, only an unambitious one who abandons a London career for the country, and only an absent-minded one who leaves his stick and not his visiting-card after waiting an hour in your room."
Translated_sentences: -- You see that I was right -- said Holmes. -- I still stand by my hypothesis that Dr. Mortimer must be courteous, for only a courteous man gets such gifts from his pacifiers; that he is not ambitious, or he would not have left London for the provinces, and that he is absent-minded, for otherwise, instead of a cane, he would have left his visiting ticket.

Sentences_from: Niechże mi pani wytłómaczy, dlaczego radzisz mu pani opuścić te strony i wracać do Londynu?
Sentences_to: Tell me why it was that you were so eager that Sir Henry should return to London."
Translated_sentences: Explain to me why you advise him to leave these parts and return to London?

Sentences_from: -- Niechże pana Bóg strzeże od takich prób!
Sentences_to: "For God's sake put such an idea out of your mind," said he.
Translated_sentences: -- God save you from such trials!

Sentences_from: Zajrzałem do tego pokoju przez drzwi uchylone. Barrymore stał pod oknem i trzymał świecę przy samej szybie.

Sentences_from: Cieszyłem się z jego uznania, na które oddawna już usiłowałem zasłużyć, stosując jego metodę badań w sprawach kryminalnych.
Sentences_to: He now took the stick from my hands and examined it for a few minutes with his naked eyes. Then with an expression of interest he laid down his cigarette, and carrying the cane to the window, he looked over it again with a convex lens.
Translated_sentences: I was pleased to receive his recognition, which I had long since tried to earn by applying his method of research to criminal cases.

Sentences_from: Biegłem za nim, ale mnie wyprzedził.

Sentences_to: If its appearance did not frighten its victim to death, at least it would paralyze the resistance which might be offered."

Sentences_to: I waited until he had passed out of sight and then I followed him.

Sentences_from: Lada chwila może wyskoczyć z za skały...

Translated_sentences: -- So -- he spoke -- it is your belief that an unclean force threatens the Baskervilles in these parts. You're a firm believer in that, aren't you?

Translated_sentences: -- so that in order to enter Elm Avenue, one must leave the house, or walk through the meadow?

Sentences_from: Nie chciała rozkochywać starego gentlemana; oni groźby, ani nawet kije nie zdołały ją skłonić do tak niecnego wspólnictwa.
Sentences_to: She would not endeavour to entangle the old gentleman in a sentimental attachment which might deliver him over to his enemy. Threats and even, I am sorry to say, blows refused to move her.
Translated_sentences: She did not wish to delight the old gentleman; they threats, nor even sticks could induce her to such unholy complicity.

Sentences_from: -- Mam przed sobą srebrny imbryk -- odparł -- ale powiedz mi, Watson, co myślisz o lasce naszego gościa?
Sentences_to: "I have, at least, a well-polished, silver-plated coffee-pot in front of me," said he. "But, tell me, Watson, what do you make of our visitor's stick?
Translated_sentences: -- I have the silver teapot before me -- he replied -- but tell me, Watson, what do you think of our guest's cane?

Sentences_from: -- Od owej tragedyi doszły do mojej świadomości fakty, sprzeczne z ogólnemi prawami natury.
Sentences_to: "Since the tragedy, Mr. Holmes, there have come to my ears several incidents which are hard to reconcile with the settled order of Nature."

Sentences_from: -- Mam w kieszeni rękopis -- rzekł doktor Jerzy Mortimer.

Sentences_from: -- Kochany panie, musisz zaufać mi ślepo i zrobić to, co powiem.

Sentences_from: Nie zastaniemy go już -- mówił Holmes.

Sentences_from: Pióro pryskało dwa razy w jednem słowie, i wyschło trzy razy przy wypisywaniu tak krótkiego adresu, co dowodzi, że było bardzo mało atramentu w kałamarzu.
Sentences_to: The pen has spluttered twice in a single word, and has run dry three times in a short address, showing that there was very little ink in the bottle.

Translated_sentences: -- We have the whole day free -- he said, rubbing his hands with joy. -- nets already set, only a butterfly missing.

Sentences_from: Onegdaj, we czwartek, doktor Mortimer był u nas na śniadaniu. Przy wykopaliskach w Long-Dawn udało mu się znaleźć czaszkę przedhistorycznego człowieka.
Sentences_to: By the way, your instructions to me never to allow Sir Henry to go out alone will become very much more onerous if a love affair were to be added to our other difficulties.

Sentences_from: Przed udaniem się na spoczynek, podniosłem roletę i wyjrzałem przez okno.

Sentences_from: Krążą tu najdziwaczniejsze legendy, przypisujące ów nagły zgon działaniu sił nadprzyrodzonych.

Sentences_from: -- Po wyjściu Watsona -- mówił baronet -- snułem się z kąta w kąt, wierny mojej obietnicy: nie zapuszczania się samemu na bagno po zachodzie słońca.
Sentences_to: "I've been moping in the house all day since Watson went off in the morning," said the baronet. "I guess I should have some credit, for I have kept my promise.

Sentences_from: Zdziwiło mnie takie pytanie. Można je było wziąć za zasadzkę, ale twarz mówiącego była chłodna i obojętna, więc moje podejrzenia musiały pierzchnąć.

Sentences_from: Obie kobiety, wplątane w tę sprawę: pani Stapleton i pani Laura Lyons, miały pewne podejrzenia; mrs. Stapleton wiedziała nawet o złych zamiarach męża względem sir Karola, a także o istnieniu psa.

Sentences_from: Rozumiesz piekielny podstęp tego łotra; tak się urządził, że nie można było znaleźć śladów zbrodni, ani wytoczyć procesu mordercy. Jedyny jego wspólnik zdradzić go nic mógł.
Sentences_to: His only accomplice was one who could never give him away, and the grotesque, inconceivable nature of the device only served to make it more effective.

Sentences_to: So paralyzed were we by the apparition that we allowed him to pass before we had recovered our nerve.

Sentences_from: Musiałem tymczasowo poprzestać na jej informacyach i zwrócić się po dalsze, w inną stronę -- ku jaskiniom naszych przedhistorycznych przodków.

Sentences_from: -- Tak, widziałem chłopca na własne oczy; z jego zachowania się można poznać, że spełnia jakąś misyę potajemną.

Translated_sentences: -- Yes, I have seen the boy with my own eyes; you can tell from his behavior that he is fulfilling some secret mission.

Sentences_from: Według wszelkiego prawdopodobieństwa, opuścił już te strony, co jest pożądanem dla mieszkańców, żyjących na pustkowiu.
Sentences_to: A fortnight has passed since his flight, during which he has not been seen and nothing has been heard of him. It is surely inconceivable that he could have held out upon the moor during all that time.
Translated_sentences: In all probability, he has already left these parts, which is desirable for the inhabitants who live in the wilderness.

Sentences_from: Stapleton -- gdyż tak go będę nazywał w dalszym ciągu -- wiedział, że sir Karol ma wadę serca i że gwałtowne wstrząśnienie może go zabić; wiedział też, że jest przesądnym i że wierzy w tę legendę.
Sentences_to: His ingenious mind instantly suggested a way by which the baronet could be done to death, and yet it would be hardly possible to bring home the guilt to the real murderer.
Translated_sentences: Stapleton -- for that is what I shall call him hereafter -- knew that Sir Charles had a defect of the heart, and that a violent concussion might kill him; he knew also that he was superstitious, and that he believed the legend.

Sentences_from: To jedno może mi szyki pomieszać.
Sentences_to: Before us lay the dark bulk of the house, its serrated roof and bristling chimneys hard outlined against the silver-spangled sky.
Translated_sentences: That's one thing that could confuse me.

Sentences_from: Warto się trudzić po takie okazy.
Sentences_to: That is where the rare plants and the butterflies are, if you have the wit to reach them."
Translated_sentences: It is worth the trouble to get such specimens.

Sentences_from: -- A jakie ślady znalazłeś pan przy furtce?
Sentences_to: "And what marks did you see by the wicket-gate?"
Translated_sentences: -- and what kind of footprints did you find at the wicket?

Sentences_from: -- Na nieszczęście, nie potrafię tego powiedzieć.
Sentences_to: "That, unfortunately, is what I cannot tell you.
Translated_sentences: -- unhappily, I can't say that.

Sentences_from: -- Jestem pewien, że będzie panu rad.
Sentences_to: "I am sure that he would be delighted."
Translated_sentences: -- I'm sure you'll be pleased.

Sentences_from: -- Obawialiśmy się tu wszyscy, że nowy baronet, po tragicznej śmierci sir Karola, nie zechce zamieszkać tutaj.
Sentences_to: "We were all rather afraid that after the sad death of Sir Charles the new baronet might refuse to live here.
Translated_sentences: -- We were all afraid here that the new baronet, after the tragic death of Sir Charles, would not want to live here.

Sentences_from: Może pan zechce obejrzeć mój zbiór motyli?
Sentences_to: I think it is the most complete one in the south-west of England.
Translated_sentences: Perhaps you would like to see my butterfly collection?

Sentences_from: Od danego miejsca dzieliło nas kilka mil, lecz mogłem wyraźnie dojrzeć czarny punkcik.
Sentences_to: It was several miles off, but I could distinctly see a small dark dot against the dull green and gray.
Translated_sentences: We were several miles from the location in question, but I could clearly see the black dot.

Sentences_from: Ścigał go zapamiętale, podskakiwał, kręcił się wkółko. Ubawiony tem przyrodniczem _intermezzo_, postanowiłem czekać na rezultat pościgu.
Sentences_to: To my dismay the creature flew straight for the great mire, and my acquaintance never paused for an instant, bounding from tuft to tuft behind it, his green net waving in the air.
Translated_sentences: He was chasing him with a fervour, jumping up and down, going round and round. Amused with this natural _intermezzo_, I decided to wait for the result of the chase.

Sentences_from: -- Watson, bierz kapelusz i laskę.
Sentences_to: "Your hat and boots, Watson, quick!
Translated_sentences: -- Watson, get your hat and cane.

Sentences_from: Ta mgła stanowi o jego życiu...
Sentences_to: There only remained the lamp in the dining-room where the two men, the murderous host and the unconscious guest, still chatted over their cigars.
Translated_sentences: This fog makes up his life...

Sentences_from: -- To bardzo prawdopodobne -- przyznał Stapleton i westchnął z widoczną ulgą, jak gdyby kamień spadł mu z serca. -- A cóż pan o tem myśli, panie Holmes?
Sentences_to: "That seems the most reasonable theory," said Stapleton, and he gave a sigh which I took to indicate his relief. "What do you think about it, Mr. Sherlock Holmes?"
Translated_sentences: -- It is very likely -- Stapleton admitted, and sighed with apparent relief, as if a stone had fallen from his heart. -- And what do you think, Mr. Holmes?

Sentences_from: Przeskakiwał z kamienia na kamień, ze skały na skałę, jak dziki kozioł.
Sentences_to: We rushed over the brow of the hill, and there was our man running with great speed down the other side, springing over the stones in his way with the activity of a mountain goat.
Translated_sentences: He leaped from stone to stone, from rock to rock, like a wild goat.

Sentences_from: -- Nie; dostrzeżono twojego chłopaka i to mi posłużyło za drogowskaz.
Sentences_to: "No, your boy had been observed, and that gave me a guide where to look."
Translated_sentences: -- No; your boyfriend was spotted and that served as a signpost for me.

Sentences_from: Z jego okrzyków miarkuję, że odbiegł spory kawał od miejsca, z którego pies go spłoszył.
Sentences_to: By his cries he must have run a long way after he knew the animal was on his track. How did he know?"
Translated_sentences: From his shouts, I measure that he ran a good distance from where the dog scolded him.

Sentences_from: -- Przepraszam; to nie jest drobiazg -- zaprzeczył detektyw. -- Jakże to było?
Sentences_to: "Exactly," said Holmes, "however foolish the incident may seem. You have lost one of your boots, you say?"
Translated_sentences: -- I'm sorry; it's not a small thing -- the detective denied it. -- how was that?

Sentences_from: Przywiozłem ze sobą Cartwrighta -- pamiętasz tego malca z hotelu -- on myślał o mnie: przynosił mi chleb i czystą bieliznę.
Sentences_to: I brought Cartwright down with me--you remember the little chap at the express office--and he has seen after my simple wants: a loaf of bread and a clean collar.
Translated_sentences: I brought Cartwright with me -- you remember the little guy from the hotel -- he thought of me: he brought me bread and clean underwear.

Sentences_from: Wśród dni słotnych kapało mu pewno na głowę, kostniał z zimna wśród chłodnych nocy, a jednak nie opuszczał swej kryjówki. Ważny cel przykuwał go zapewne do tej nory...
Sentences_to: When I thought of the heavy rains and looked at the gaping roof I understood how strong and immutable must be the purpose which had kept him in that inhospitable abode.
Translated_sentences: It must have dripped on his head during the rainy days, he must have grown cold during the cold nights, but he never left his hiding place. An important purpose must have drawn him to this burrow...

Sentences_from: Wprawdzie według rysopisu dorożkarza, rzekomy Sherlock Holmes był niższego wzrostu, lecz rysopisy bywają niedokładne.
Sentences_to: The beard might well have been the same. The cabman had described a somewhat shorter man, but such an impression might easily have been erroneous.
Translated_sentences: Admittedly, according to the carriage driver's drawing, the alleged Sherlock Holmes was shorter in stature, but drawings are sometimes inaccurate.

Sentences_from: -- Czy jaśnie pan każe podać obiad? -- zapytał.
Sentences_to: "Would you wish dinner to be served at once, sir?"
Translated_sentences: -- Will your lordship please serve dinner? -- he asked.

Sentences_from: Dalej, rozumiałem, że gdyby utwierdziła się wiara w nadprzyrodzone siły, rządzące w Baskerville Hall, nikt nie zechciałby objąć starego zamku w posiadanie.
Sentences_to: I had the further motive that Baskerville Hall, as the paper says, would certainly remain untenanted if anything were done to increase its already rather grim reputation.
Translated_sentences: Further, I understood that if the belief in supernatural forces ruling at Baskerville Hall were to be confirmed, no one would want to take possession of the old castle.

Sentences_from: Pomiędzy nimi leżała dziewczyna, martwa, a obok niej Hugon Baskerville -- nieżywy.
Sentences_to: The moon was shining bright upon the clearing, and there in the centre lay the unhappy maid where she had fallen, dead of fear and of fatigue. But it was not the sight of her body, nor yet was it that of the body of Hugo Baskerville lying near her, which raised the hair upon the heads of these three daredevil roysterers, but it was that, standing over Hugo, and plucking at his throat, there stood a foul thing, a great, black beast, shaped like a hound, yet larger than any hound that ever mortal eye has rested upon.
Translated_sentences: Between them lay the girl, dead, and beside her Hugon Baskerville -- dead.

Sentences_from: Stojąc przy tej furtce, biedny sir Karol ujrzał coś, co go tak wystraszyło, że stracił przytomność i zaczął biedz prosto przed siebie, aż mu tchu zbrakło i padł nieżywy z wycieńczenia i trwogi.
Sentences_to: As the old man stood there he saw something coming across the moor, something which terrified him so that he lost his wits, and ran and ran until he died of sheer horror and exhaustion.
Translated_sentences: Standing at this wicket, poor Sir Charles saw something that so frightened him that he lost consciousness, and began to run straight before him until he was out of breath and fell down dead from exhaustion and fright.

Sentences_from: W blasku księżyca widziałem wyraźnie drobną postać naturalisty. Spostrzegłszy nas, zatrzymał się, ale po chwili szedł dalej.
Sentences_to: Not a word to show your suspicions--not a word, or my plans crumble to the ground."
Translated_sentences: In the moonlight I could clearly see the small figure of the naturalist. When he saw us, he stopped, but after a while he continued walking.

Sentences_from: Może jeszcze nie zapóźno, może zdołam go dogonić... Podążyłem w kierunku, w którym sir Henryk odszedł, ale nic mogłem go dostrzedz, aż wreszcie ukazał mi się na zakręcie drogi, tam, gdzie ścieżka, wiodąca przez trzęsawisko, odbiega od gościńca.
Sentences_to: But when I came to think the matter over my conscience reproached me bitterly for having on any pretext allowed him to go out of my sight.
Translated_sentences: Perhaps it is not too late, perhaps I can catch up with him... I followed the direction in which Sir Henry had gone, but I could not see him, till at last he appeared to me at the bend of the road, where the path leading through the moor diverges from the track.

Sentences_from: A gdzieżby chodził, i po co, jeśli nie dla prowiantowania więźnia?
Sentences_to: He passes along the same path at the same hour, and to whom should he be going except to the convict?"
Translated_sentences: And where would he go, and for what, if not to victual the prisoner?

Sentences_from: Jak uważasz: co nam teraz uczynić należy?
Sentences_to: What do you think we should do?"
Translated_sentences: What do you think we should do now?

Sentences_from: O dwieście yardów przed domem, Sherlock kazał nam stanąć.
Sentences_to: We moved cautiously along the track as if we were bound for the house, but Holmes halted us when we were about two hundred yards from it.
Translated_sentences: About two hundred yards ahead, Sherlock told us to stand.

Sentences_from: Bądź co bądź, znajdowałem się wobec kobiety ślicznej, i teraz dopiero uczułem, ze moje zadanie jest trudne.
Sentences_to: But these, of course, are after-thoughts. At the moment I was simply conscious that I was in the presence of a very handsome woman, and that she was asking me the reasons for my visit.
Translated_sentences: After all, I was facing a lovely woman, and only now did I feel that my task was difficult.

Sentences_from: Donosiłem ci już, że, sądząc ze słów pocztmistrza, doszedłem do przekonania, iż ta próba niczego nie dowiodła.
Sentences_to: I have already explained that the testimony of the postmaster shows that the test was worthless and that we have no proof one way or the other.
Translated_sentences: I have already reported to you that, judging from the words of the postmaster, I have come to the conviction that this attempt has proved nothing.

Sentences_from: Obawiałem się zawsze anewryzmu serca, bo byłem bardzo do niego przywiązany.
Sentences_to: I feared that some disaster might occur, for I was very fond of the old man, and I knew that his heart was weak."
Translated_sentences: I was always afraid of the anevrism of the heart, because I was very attached to it.

Sentences_from: Ożeniłem się i dlatego musiałem szpital opuścić; trzeba było założyć dom, postarać się o praktykę samodzielną.
Sentences_to: I married, and so left the hospital, and with it all hopes of a consulting practice. It was necessary to make a home of my own."
Translated_sentences: I got married and that's why I had to leave the hospital; we had to set up a home, try to practice independently.

Sentences_from: -- Ani w dzień śmierci sir Karola?... -- rzekłem z naciskiem.
Sentences_to: "Not on the very day of Sir Charles's death?"
Translated_sentences: -- Nor on the day Sir Charles died? -- I said with emphasis.

Sentences_from: Przenosił wzrok z Holmesa na mnie i ze mnie na Holmesa.
Sentences_to: He looked sharply from Holmes to me.
Translated_sentences: He shifted his gaze from Holmes to me and from me to Holmes.

Sentences_from: Pan Stapleton mówił to z uśmiechem, ale z oczu jego było widać, że przywiązuje wiarę do tych pogłosek. -- Owa legenda oddziałała na wyobraźnię sir Karola -- ciągnął dalej -- i pewien jestem, że sprowadziła śmierć nagłą.
Sentences_to: He spoke with a smile, but I seemed to read in his eyes that he took the matter more seriously. "The story took a great hold upon the imagination of Sir Charles, and I have no doubt that it led to his tragic end."
Translated_sentences: Mr. Stapleton said this with a smile, but you could see from his eyes that he attached credence to these rumours. -- This legend had affected Sir Charles's imagination -- he went on -- and I am sure it brought on sudden death.

Sentences_from: Ożenił się tam z Beryl Garcia, najpiękniejszą kobietą w Costa-Rica, a sprzeniewierzywszy znaczną sumę z publicznych funduszów, zmienił nazwisko na Vandeleur, uciekł do Anglii i założył szkołę dla chłopców w Yorkshire.
Sentences_to: He married Beryl Garcia, one of the beauties of Costa Rica, and, having purloined a considerable sum of public money, he changed his name to Vandeleur and fled to England, where he established a school in the east of Yorkshire.
Translated_sentences: There he married Beryl Garcia, the most beautiful woman in Costa-Rica, and having embezzled a considerable sum from public funds, he changed his name to Vandeleur, fled to England and established a school for boys in Yorkshire.

Sentences_from: Nasz wspólny przyjaciel, pan Stapleton, był tego samego zdania.
Sentences_to: Mr. Stapleton, a mutual friend who was much concerned at his state of health, was of the same opinion.
Translated_sentences: Our mutual friend, Mr. Stapleton, was of the same opinion.

Sentences_from: Muzeum Brytańskie objaśniło mnie, że był powagą na polu owadoznawstwa; odkrył dużo gatunków, które noszą nazwisko Vandeleur.
Sentences_to: "We now come to that portion of his life which has proved to be of such intense interest to us. The fellow had evidently made inquiry and found that only two lives intervened between him and a valuable estate.
Translated_sentences: The British Museum explained to me that he was a soothsayer in the field of insect science; he discovered a lot of species that bear the name Vandeleur.

Sentences_from: Zwykle dostawał dużo listów, bo wiedziano o jego dobrem sercu, i każdy w kłopocie udawał się do niego.
Sentences_to: He had usually a great many letters, for he was a public man and well known for his kind heart, so that everyone who was in trouble was glad to turn to him.
Translated_sentences: He usually got a lot of letters, because his good heart was known, and anyone in trouble went to him.

Sentences_from: Łatwo mi przyszło dowiedzieć się o adresie mrs. Lyons.
Sentences_to: When I reached Coombe Tracey I told Perkins to put up the horses, and I made inquiries for the lady whom I had come to interrogate.
Translated_sentences: It was easy for me to find out the address of mrs. Lyons.

Sentences_from: Odetchnęła swobodniej. -- Dzięki Bogu! Widzicie, panowie, jak ten łotr obszedł się ze mną!...
Sentences_to: She gave a long sigh of satisfaction.
Translated_sentences: She breathed more freely. -- Thank God! You see, gentlemen, how that villain has dealt with me!...

Sentences_from: Podróż była przyjemna; czas zeszedł mi na zawiązywaniu bliższej znajomości z moimi towarzyszami i na bawieniu się z pieskiem doktora Mortimera.
Sentences_to: I looked back at the platform when we had left it far behind, and saw the tall, austere figure of Holmes standing motionless and gazing after us.
Translated_sentences: The journey was pleasant; my time passed in forming a closer acquaintance with my companions, and in playing with Dr. Mortimer's dog.

Sentences_from: Po chwili wydał cichy okrzyk zadowolnienia. Spojrzałem w kierunku jego wzroku i zobaczyłem, że dorożka z siedzącym w niej mężczyzną, która zatrzymała się po drugiej stronie ulicy, jedzie znowu dalej.
Sentences_to: An instant afterwards he gave a little cry of satisfaction, and, following the direction of his eager eyes, I saw that a hansom cab with a man inside which had halted on the other side of the street was now proceeding slowly onward again.
Translated_sentences: After a moment he gave a quiet cry of satisfaction. I looked in the direction of his vision and saw that the carriage with the man sitting in it, which had stopped on the other side of the street, was going on again.

Sentences_from: Wychodziliśmy zawsze pod opieką tajnego policyanta, który nic podejrzanego nie dostrzegł.
Sentences_to: We have never gone out without keeping a sharp watch, and no one could have escaped our notice."
Translated_sentences: We always left under the protection of an undercover policeman who saw nothing suspicious.

Sentences_from: Lubi wprowadzać w zdumienie i zachwyt nad swym geniuszem wywiadowczym.
Sentences_to: The great ordeal was in front of us; at last we were about to make our final effort, and yet Holmes had said nothing, and I could only surmise what his course of action would be.
Translated_sentences: He likes to bring wonder and awe to his intelligence genius.

Sentences_from: -- Bynajmniej. Zatrzymałem się u znajomego -- odparł doktor. -- Nie było żadnych poszlak, wskazujących, że chcemy stanąć w tym właśnie hotelu.
Sentences_to: "No, I had been staying with a friend," said the doctor. "There was no possible indication that we intended to go to this hotel."
Translated_sentences: -- Not at all. I was staying with a friend -- -- there was no indication that we wanted to stay at this particular hotel.

Sentences_from: Nigdy jeszcze nie widziałem go tak bezradnym.
Sentences_to: He stamped his feet upon the ground.
Translated_sentences: I've never seen him so helpless before.

Sentences_from: Zaopatrzyliśmy go we wszystko, czego mu potrzeba.
Sentences_to: We have provided him with all that he can want.
Translated_sentences: We supplied him with everything he needed.

Sentences_from: Morderca wodził niespokojnym wzrokiem dokoła, jak zwierz, gdy go doleci odgłos nagonki.
Sentences_to: The light beneath him was reflected in his small, cunning eyes which peered fiercely to right and left through the darkness, like a crafty and savage animal who has heard the steps of the hunters.
Translated_sentences: The murderer wandered around with anxious eyes, like an animal when the sound of a rebuke gets to him.

Sentences_from: Wszystko mi sprzyjało; postanawiałem skorzystać z okoliczności i dziś jeszcze tę tajemnicę wykryć.
Sentences_to: Everything was working in my favour, and I swore that it should not be through lack of energy or perseverance that I should miss the chance which fortune had thrown in my way.
Translated_sentences: Everything favored me; I resolved to take advantage of the circumstances and to-day still detect this mystery.

Sentences_from: -- To zależy od rasy -- tłómaczył doktor Mortimer. -- Dość spojrzeć na okrągłą czaszkę sir Henryka, aby poznać, że jest celtyckiego pochodzenia, a Celtowie mają wrodzony zapał i zdolność przywiązywania się do ludzi i kraju.
Sentences_to: "It depends upon the breed of men quite as much as on the county," said Dr. Mortimer. "A glance at our friend here reveals the rounded head of the Celt, which carries inside it the Celtic enthusiasm and power of attachment.
Translated_sentences: -- It depends on the race -- Dr. Mortimer explained. -- One need only look at Sir Henry's round skull to know that he is of Celtic descent, and Celts have an innate zeal and capacity for attachment to people and country.

Sentences_from: -- Jest kilka legatów na drobne sumki i duży zapis na cele dobroczynne.
Sentences_to: "There were many insignificant sums to individuals, and a large number of public charities.
Translated_sentences: -- There are several legacies for small amounts and a large bequest for charity.

Sentences_from: Byliśmy tak przerażeni tem zjawiskiem, że nie wystrzeliliśmy w porę. Pies przebiegł mimo nas.
Sentences_to: With long bounds the huge black creature was leaping down the track, following hard upon the footsteps of our friend.
Translated_sentences: We were so terrified by this phenomenon that we didn't fire in time. The dog ran in front of us.

Sentences_from: -- Wątpię, czy co wieczór po dziesięć minut stawał przy furtce.
Sentences_to: "I think it unlikely that he waited at the moor-gate every evening.
Translated_sentences: -- I doubt if he stood at the wicket for ten minutes each night.

Sentences_from: Jest uradowany. Trudno o większego entuzyastę i maniaka.
Sentences_to: My popularity would soon suffer if I were to carry out your orders to the letter.
Translated_sentences: He's thrilled. It's hard to find a bigger enthusiast and geek.

Sentences_from: Przysięgam sobie, że muszę ją odkryć, i to w ciągu dwudziestu czterech godzin.
Sentences_to: I swear that another day shall not have passed before I have done all that man can do to reach the heart of the mystery.
Translated_sentences: I swear to myself that I must discover it, and within twenty-four hours.

Sentences_from: -- Zatem wiesz, że drugi człowiek kryje się na bagnie?
Sentences_to: "You know that there is another man then?"
Translated_sentences: -- So you know the other man is hiding in the swamp?

Sentences_from: -- Ale czemu o takiej godzinie?...
Sentences_to: "But why at such an hour?"
Translated_sentences: -- But why at this hour?

Sentences_from: Daleko, w stronie Grimpen-Mire, błyszczało żółte światełko.
Sentences_to: Far away, miles off, in the direction of Grimpen, a single steady yellow light was shining.
Translated_sentences: Far away, on the Grimpen-Mire side, a yellow light shone.

Sentences_from: Wiedziałem, że samotność jest niezbędną mojemu przyjacielowi w chwilach, gdy zastanawiał się nad poszlakami spraw kryminalnych, gdy wyciągał wnioski i tworzył teorye, które okazywały się zawsze słusznemi.
Sentences_to: I knew that seclusion and solitude were very necessary for my friend in those hours of intense mental concentration during which he weighed every particle of evidence, constructed alternative theories, balanced one against the other, and made up his mind as to which points were essential and which immaterial.
Translated_sentences: I knew that solitude was necessary for my friend in the moments when he pondered the clues of criminal cases, when he drew conclusions and formed theories that always proved correct.

Sentences_from: -- Jaśnie panie, byłoby to szaleństwem z jego strony.
Sentences_to: "He would not do anything so mad, sir.
Translated_sentences: -- Your Lordship, that would be madness on his part.

Sentences_from: Ale w jaki sposób? Przedewszystkiem należało dowiedzieć się od pocztmistrza w Grimpen, czy telegram został oddany do własnych rąk Barrymora.
Sentences_to: Obviously the first thing to do was to see the Grimpen postmaster, and find whether the test telegram had really been placed in Barrymore's own hands. Be the answer what it might, I should at least have something to report to Sherlock Holmes.
Translated_sentences: But how? First of all, it was necessary to find out from the postmaster at Grimpen whether the telegram had been delivered into Barrymor's own hands.

Sentences_from: Takie wysnuwałem wnioski; opowiadam ci je, chociaż rezultat wykazał ich bezpodstawność.
Sentences_to: He was less surprised than I had expected.
Translated_sentences: These were the conclusions I drew; I tell you them, though the result has shown them to be unfounded.

Sentences_from: Otóż zaleciała mnie subtelna woń białego jaśminu.
Sentences_to: In doing so I held it within a few inches of my eyes, and was conscious of a faint smell of the scent known as white jessamine.
Translated_sentences: Well, I was attracted by the subtle scent of white jasmine.

Sentences_from: Któżby miał ochotę mnie śledzić? Nikt mnie tu nie zna.
Sentences_to: You have nothing else to report to us before we go into this matter?"
Translated_sentences: Who would want to follow me? Nobody knows me here.

Sentences_from: Słysząc ich pijackie wrzaski, dziewczyna truchlała, lecz była z natury dzielną, więc opanowała strach i postanowiła ratować się. Ogromna brzoza osłaniała i do dziś dnia osłania okno tej narożnej komnaty.
Sentences_to: Now, the poor lass upstairs was like to have her wits turned at the singing and shouting and terrible oaths which came up to her from below, for they say that the words used by Hugo Baskerville, when he was in wine, were such as might blast the man who said them.
Translated_sentences: Hearing their drunken screams, the girl trembled, but she was brave by nature, so she conquered her fear and decided to save herself. A huge birch tree sheltered the window of this corner chamber, and still does to this day.

Sentences_from: Gdybym nie ufał pańskiej odwadze i zimnej krwi, nie dawałbym panu takiej rady. Wierzaj mi pan, że to jest niezbędne.
Sentences_to: If I had not every confidence in your nerve and courage I would not suggest it, but it is essential that you should do it."
Translated_sentences: If I did not trust your courage and cold bloodedness, I would not give you such advice. Believe me it is essential.

Sentences_from: -- To zależy od tego, dokąd pan idzie; jeżeli na łąkę i bagno, pójdę z panem.
Sentences_to: "That depends on whether you are going on the moor," said I.
Translated_sentences: -- It depends on where you are going; if to a meadow and a swamp, I will go with you.

Sentences_from: Sir Henryk Baskerville słuchał uważnie, przerywając od czasu do czasu okrzykiem zdziwienia.
Sentences_to: Sir Henry Baskerville listened with the deepest attention, and with an occasional exclamation of surprise.
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry Baskerville listened attentively, interrupting now and then with an exclamation of surprise.

Sentences_from: -- Mogę to tylko wywnioskować, że przed osiedleniem się na wsi, ten lekarz praktykował w mieście.
Sentences_to: "I can only think of the obvious conclusion that the man has practised in town before going to the country."
Translated_sentences: -- I can only infer that before settling in the village, this doctor practiced in the city.

Sentences_from: -- Jedno jest tylko miejsce, w którem mógł się schronić: dawna kopalnia ołowiu, w samym środku moczarów.
Sentences_to: "There is but one place where he can have fled," she answered. "There is an old tin mine on an island in the heart of the mire.
Translated_sentences: -- There is only one place he could have taken refuge: a former lead mine, in the middle of the swamps.

Sentences_from: Przez półtory godziny zapomniał o tej dziwnej sprawie; pochłonęły go obrazy nowoczesnych mistrzów belgijskich, mówił tylko o sztuce, na którą miał poglądy bardzo oryginalne. O naznaczonej godzinie stanęliśmy przed Northumberland Hotel.
Sentences_to: For two hours the strange business in which we had been involved appeared to be forgotten, and he was entirely absorbed in the pictures of the modern Belgian masters. He would talk of nothing but art, of which he had the crudest ideas, from our leaving the gallery until we found ourselves at the Northumberland Hotel.
Translated_sentences: For an hour and a half he forgot the strange affair; he was absorbed in the paintings of the modern Belgian masters, and spoke only of art, on which he had very original views. At the appointed hour we stood before the Northumberland Hotel.

Sentences_from: Istotnie ujrzałem malca, niosącego zawiniątko na plecach. Wspinał się pod górę powoli.
Sentences_to: There he was, sure enough, a small urchin with a little bundle upon his shoulder, toiling slowly up the hill.
Translated_sentences: Indeed, I saw a little boy carrying a bundle on his back. He climbed up the hill slowly.

Sentences_from: Usłyszawszy, że sir Karol, z porady doktora Mortimer, zamierza opuścić Baskerville-Hall, postanowił działać bezwłocznie, w obawie, aby ofiara nie wysunęła się z jego szponów.
Sentences_to: "Driving back in the evening from Coombe Tracey he was in time to get his hound, to treat it with his infernal paint, and to bring the beast round to the gate at which he had reason to expect that he would find the old gentleman waiting.
Translated_sentences: Having heard that Sir Charles, by the advice of Dr. Mortimer, intended to leave Baskerville-Hall, he resolved to act without delay, for fear lest the victim should slip from his clutches.

Sentences_from: -- Urwała się trzecia nić! -- zawołał Holmes. -- To sprytny hultaj!
Sentences_to: "Snap goes our third thread, and we end where we began," said he.
Translated_sentences: -- The third thread has broken! -- cried Holmes. -- He's a clever bastard!

Sentences_from: -- Czyś pan kiedy słyszał wabienie błotnego ptaka, zwanego bąkiem?
Sentences_to: "Well, perhaps it was. Did you ever hear a bittern booming?"
Translated_sentences: -- Have you ever heard the lure of a mud bird called a bittern?

Sentences_from: -- Jeżeli panowie przyjrzycie mu się dokładnie, to zmiarkujecie, że piszący miał kłopot z piórem i atramentem.
Sentences_to: "If you examine it carefully you will see that both the pen and the ink have given the writer trouble.
Translated_sentences: -- If you gentlemen will look at it closely, you will moderate that the writer had trouble with his pen and ink.

Sentences_from: -- Zaczniesz od dania szylinga portyerowi.
Sentences_to: "You will begin in each case by giving the outside porter one shilling.
Translated_sentences: -- you start by giving a shilling to the porter.

Sentences_from: Bądź co bądź urozmaica nam jednostajność życia i wprowadza do niego trochę komicznego pierwiastku.
Sentences_to: He helps to keep our lives from being monotonous and gives a little comic relief where it is badly needed.
Translated_sentences: After all, it diversifies the uniformity of our lives and introduces a little comic element to it.

Sentences_from: W pierwszej chwili sądziłem, że to intryga miłosna. Dlatego zakradał się boso, dlatego był niespokojny.
Sentences_to: But whatever the true explanation of Barrymore's movements might be, I felt that the responsibility of keeping them to myself until I could explain them was more than I could bear.
Translated_sentences: At first I thought it was a love plot. That's why he was sneaking around barefoot, that's why he was restless.

Sentences_from: Zabił się na miejscu, bo skała wysoka i z tej strony prostopadle spuszcza się w kotlinę; druga jej strona łączy się z płaskowzgórzem. Biegnąc, więzień w przerażeniu swem nie spostrzegł, że stoi nad przepaścią.
Sentences_to: He has rushed about the moor in a crazy state and eventually fallen over here and broken his neck."
Translated_sentences: He killed himself on the spot, because the rock was high and on this side it descended perpendicularly into a valley; its other side joined the plateau. While running, the prisoner, in his terror, did not notice that he was standing over a precipice.

Sentences_from: Sir Henryk otworzył je; chłodny wiatr smagnął nas po twarzach.
Sentences_to: Sir Henry had flung it open, and the cold night wind beat in upon our faces.
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry opened them; a cool wind streaked our faces.

Sentences_from: Po co tamten ukrywa się na bagnie?...
Sentences_to: Look at the noises on the moor at night. There's not a man would cross it after sundown if he was paid for it.
Translated_sentences: Why is he hiding in the swamp?

Sentences_from: W mgnieniu oka rozerwaliśmy pęta; na ziemi u stóp naszych leżała pani Stapleton.
Sentences_to: In a minute we had torn off the gag, unswathed the bonds, and Mrs. Stapleton sank upon the floor in front of us.
Translated_sentences: In a flash we had torn the bonds; on the ground at our feet lay Mrs. Stapleton.

Sentences_from: Wchodząc, zobaczył odrazu laskę w ręku Holmesa i podbiegł ku niej z okrzykiem radości. -- Tak się cieszę! -- zawołał. -- Nie byłem pewny, czym ją zostawił tutaj, czy w biurze portowem.
Sentences_to: As he entered his eyes fell upon the stick in Holmes's hand, and he ran towards it with an exclamation of joy. "I am so very glad," said he.
Translated_sentences: On entering he saw the cane in Holmes' hand and ran towards it with a shout of joy. -- I'm so glad! -- he cried. -- I wasn't sure whether he left it here or in the harbor office.

Sentences_from: Po śmierci sir Karola zasięgaliśmy wiadomości o tym gentlemanie i dowiedzieliśmy się, że ma fermę w Kanadzie.
Sentences_to: On the death of Sir Charles we inquired for this young gentleman and found that he had been farming in Canada.
Translated_sentences: After Sir Charles' death we inquired after the gentleman, and learned that he had a farm in Canada.

Sentences_from: Hojność sir Karola dostarczyła nam środków po temu.
Sentences_to: Sir Charles's generosity has given us the means to do so.
Translated_sentences: Sir Charles' generosity has provided us with the means to do so.

Sentences_from: Czy zastanawiałeś się w ciągu dnia nad tą sprawą?
Sentences_to: Have you turned the case over in your mind?"
Translated_sentences: Have you thought about this issue during the day?

Sentences_from: -- A potem wyczytałaś pani wiadomość o śmierci w gazecie miejscowej?
Sentences_to: "He appears to be a very consistent character. And then you heard nothing until you read the reports of the death in the paper?"
Translated_sentences: -- and then you read the news of the death in the local paper?

Sentences_from: Pytaj mnie pan, o co tylko chcesz -- nic nie zataję.
Sentences_to: Ask me what you like, and there is nothing which I shall hold back.
Translated_sentences: Ask me anything you want -- I won't withhold anything.

Sentences_from: Po wyjściu naszych gości, Holmes zerwał się i zawołał:
Sentences_to: In an instant Holmes had changed from the languid dreamer to the man of action.
Translated_sentences: After our guests had left, Holmes broke off and called out:

Sentences_from: -- Czy historya ta nie jest interesującą?
Sentences_to: "Do you not find it interesting?"
Translated_sentences: -- Isn't that story interesting?

Sentences_from: Minąwszy najgłębsze moczary, szukaliśmy odbicia stóp na twardym już gruncie. Nadaremnie.
Sentences_to: But no slightest sign of them ever met our eyes. If the earth told a true story, then Stapleton never reached that island of refuge towards which he struggled through the fog upon that last night.
Translated_sentences: Having passed the deepest swamps, we were looking for the reflection of our feet on the hard ground. In vain.

Sentences_from: -- Dojrzał go zapewne stary gentleman przez teleskop.
Sentences_to: "The old gentleman with the telescope, no doubt.
Translated_sentences: -- He was probably reached by an old gentleman through a telescope.

Sentences_from: -- Przypuszczam, że skłonił panią, dowodząc, że sir Karol chętnie poniesie wydatki na rozwód.
Sentences_to: "I presume that the reason he gave was that you would receive help from Sir Charles for the legal expenses connected with your divorce?"
Translated_sentences: -- I suppose he induced you by proving that Sir Charles would gladly bear the expense of a divorce.

Sentences_from: Przeszedł ścieżką obok nas i podążył dalej, a idąc, oglądał się na prawo i lewo, z widocznym niepokojem. -- Pst! -- szepnął Holmes. -- Baczność!
Sentences_to: "We are going too far," said Holmes. "We dare not take the chance of his being overtaken before he can reach us. At all costs we must hold our ground where we are." He dropped on his knees and clapped his ear to the ground. "Thank God, I think that I hear him coming."
Translated_sentences: He crossed the path beside us and followed on, and as he went he looked to right and left, with evident anxiety. -- Pst! -- whispered Holmes. -- attention!

Sentences_from: -- Panie Holmes -- rzekła wreszcie -- ten człowiek obiecywał, że mnie poślubi, jeśli uzyskam rozwód.
Sentences_to: "Mr. Holmes," she said, "this man had offered me marriage on condition that I could get a divorce from my husband. He has lied to me, the villain, in every conceivable way.
Translated_sentences: -- Mr. Holmes -- she said at last -- this man promised to marry me if I obtained a divorce.

Sentences_from: -- Nie tak łatwo go opisać. Miał może lat czterdzieści, był średniego wzrostu, ze dwa cale niższy od pana, ubrany był porządnie, miał dużą, czarną brodę, przyciętą spiczasto, i był bardzo blady.
Sentences_to: The cabman scratched his head. "Well, he wasn't altogether such an easy gentleman to describe. I'd put him at forty years of age, and he was of a middle height, two or three inches shorter than you, sir. He was dressed like a toff, and he had a black beard, cut square at the end, and a pale face. I don't know as I could say more than that."
Translated_sentences: -- Not so easy to describe. He was perhaps forty years of age, of medium height, about two inches shorter than you, dressed decently, with a large, black beard, trimmed pointedly, and was very pale.

Sentences_from: Cieszyło ją to widocznie, choć nie chciała słuchać moich wynurzeń miłosnych.
Sentences_to: I told her that since I had seen her I was in no hurry to leave it, and that if she really wanted me to go, the only way to work it was for her to arrange to go with me.
Translated_sentences: Apparently she was happy about this, although she did not want to listen to my amorous outbursts.

Sentences_from: Serce zabiło we mnie żywiej. Tu musiał przebywać nieznajomy.
Sentences_to: Throwing aside my cigarette, I closed my hand upon the butt of my revolver and, walking swiftly up to the door, I looked in. The place was empty.
Translated_sentences: My heart beat faster inside me. This must be where the stranger was staying.

Sentences_from: -- Widzi pan te wzgórza woddali?
Sentences_to: "Well, you see the hills beyond?
Translated_sentences: -- do you see those hills of woddala?

Sentences_from: Mieliśmy się dowiedzieć jeszcze innych szczegółów, choć wiele rzeczy pozostało niewyjaśnionych.
Sentences_to: But more than that we were never destined to know, though there was much which we might surmise.
Translated_sentences: We were to find out other details, though many things remained unexplained.

Sentences_from: Poczciwy doktor okazuje nam dużo życzliwości, odwiedza nas prawie codzień.
Sentences_to: He has been very attentive to us, and hardly a day has passed that he has not called at the Hall to see how we were getting on.
Translated_sentences: The kind doctor shows us a lot of kindness and visits us almost every day.

Sentences_from: -- Wkraczamy teraz w dziedzinę domysłów -- wtrącił doktor Mortimer.
Sentences_to: "We are coming now rather into the region of guesswork," said Dr. Mortimer.
Translated_sentences: -- We are now entering the realm of conjecture -- interjected Dr. Mortimer.

Sentences_from: Tu -- domek przyrodnika Stapleton. Tutaj dwie formy: High Tore i Fulmire.
Sentences_to: There is a house indicated here which may be the residence of the naturalist--Stapleton, if I remember right, was his name.
Translated_sentences: Here -- naturalist Stapleton's house. Here two forms: High Tore and Fulmire.

Sentences_from: Wiesz zapewne, że pomiędzy tą damą a Stapletonem zachodzą bardzo blizkie stosunki?...
Sentences_to: You are aware, perhaps, that a close intimacy exists between this lady and the man Stapleton?"
Translated_sentences: You must know that there is a very close relationship between this lady and Stapleton...

Sentences_from: Kochany Holmes! Moje poprzednie listy i depesze powiadamiały cię dokładnie i szczegółowo o wszystkiem, co się działo w tym ponurym zakątku.
Sentences_to: MY DEAR HOLMES,--My previous letters and telegrams have kept you pretty well up to date as to all that has occurred in this most God-forsaken corner of the world. The longer one stays here the more does the spirit of the moor sink into one's soul, its vastness, and also its grim charm.
Translated_sentences: Dear Holmes! My previous letters and dispatches have informed you exactly and in detail of all that has been going on in this dreary corner.

Sentences_from: W pierwszej chwili mój szwagier miał go za szpiega, ale niebawem przekonał się, że to gentleman i że działa na własną rękę w jakimś celu tajemniczym.
Sentences_to: At first he thought that he was the police, but soon he found that he had some lay of his own. A kind of gentleman he was, as far as he could see, but what he was doing he could not make out."
Translated_sentences: At first my brother-in-law thought him a spy, but he soon became convinced that he was a gentleman and that he was acting on his own for some mysterious purpose.

Sentences_from: Czyżby Barrymore upatrywał kogoś lub czegoś na bagnie?
Sentences_to: It had struck me that it was possible that some love intrigue was on foot. That would have accounted for his stealthy movements and also for the uneasiness of his wife.
Translated_sentences: Could it be that Barrymore is looking for someone or something in the swamp?
